Description: Solid-cast mirror in copper alloy; circular shape with a simple stepped projecting tang to which was attached a missing handle; flat, plain surface; very heavy; corroded.
Curator's comments: Mirrors had more than a pure domestic function. According to iconographic and archaeological evidences, they could be an object of cult, either offered as an ex-voto or part of the funerary equipment (Robinson 2010, 219-220). A mirror of similar shape was discovered in Herakleion-Thonis (Robinson 2010, fig. 19.1). This mirror is very heavy (almost 1kg) which could be an indication of its votive function. Robinson, Z. 2010, ‘Living with Metals in Hellenistic Egypt – New Finds from Heraclion-Thonis’, in D. Robinson and A. Wilson (eds.), Alexandria and the North-West Delta, Oxford, 219–231.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (RA.05)
